Through sharing of experiences and best practices with two of the best European Science Centres, Esplora aims to better reach the following strategic values: a) Connecting with Visitors, b) Science Education, c) Scientific Hub for the Community, d) Science Communication, e) Sustainability, f) Esplora Culture.
Number and profile of participants: 16 Esplora Staff member from the Education Team (Programme Developers and Science Communicators), Front of House (Visitor Services and Guidance Receptionists), the Communication Team (Marketing, Public Relations and Creative), Quality Assurance, the Lead Programme Developers and Duty Managers. All of these participants work in a context of a non-formal STEAM vet-related education programme for students and the general public.
Description of activities: This project is composed of 3 activities; 2 staff mobility experiences at Heureka Science Centre in Finland, focusing on different aspects of Science Communication and Education and 1 staff mobility experience at Glasgow Science Centre focusing on Evidence-based Management in Science Communication through the My World of Work Exhibition.
Methodology to be used in carrying out the project: Firstly, the joint agreements with the 2 Science Centres have already been made and agreed. Then the participants will be carefully and meritocratically selected through an expression of interest followed by careful preparation and guidance with each and every participant. The Job Shadowing experiences will be held in Early and Late September 2018 and in Mid-February 2019. Finally, all participants will be required to hold train the trainer sessions with the rest of their teams, write an article about their experience to be uploaded on EPALE, Esplora Website/Blog, Esplora's Social Media or the School Education Gateway and finally contribute to a short training seminar for the general public to be held in collaboration with MCAST on VET.
A short description of the Results and impact envisaged:  • this staff mobility will be regarded as an opportunity for Esplora staff to learn from and to share best practices and experiences in the field of VET and Science Communication, to allow for self development, capacity building and personal growth and to allow individual staff members/teams to view processes they are involved in from a different angle. The impact envisaged will be that of creating better tailor-made education programmes, events and offer better visitor experiences and guidance on a day-to-day basis to school students and the general public. 
Potential longer term benefits: More uptake of Science and VET subjects at form 2, more uptake of Science and VET courses and careers at a local level. More awareness on VET and Science Communication.
Mobility as a Catalyst for Apprentice Success

Adjuvant Limited, since it's incorporation in May 2009, has been involved in the delivery and financial management of EU Vocational Education and Scottish Government projects with the cumulative project values exceeding £7 Million. 

This application for VET learner mobility on behalf of apprentices employed as professional players at seven Scottish football clubs (our sending partners). Mobility will comprise 156 mobility VET learners, the majority being apprentices, and 33 accompanying persons who will travel to  Spain, Portugal and Turkey. This may seem like large mobility project but the experience of our staff in European mobility is unparalleled with over 50 years of collective experience in Leonardo da Vinci and Erasmus+ project management and delivery. 

Evidence from previous mobility projects has shown that success rates for Scottish mobility participants in being offered a professional contract can be dramatically increased through participation in European mobility, with a 2-3 fold increase in the likelihood of apprentices becoming professional footballers. 

Another value-added benefit of mobility participation is the finding that apprentices who are unsuccessful in being offered a professional contract are significantly more likely to be offered employment in a secondary career pathway than those who have not undertaken mobility. Unemployment among mobility participants is less than 4%, compared to 45% unemployment in peers from other Scottish clubs who have not undertaken mobility. The consequential improvement in informal learning, soft skills, cultural awareness and linguistic abilities as a result of mobility has proven to be a major deciding factor for employers. 

This mobility project will enhance the employability of Scottish apprentices and allow them to experience the culture, language and training methods at an acknowledged (UEFA) Centre of Excellence, which is applauded as having world class record in talent identification, innovative coaching and player development.  

The project objectives are:
1. Improved tactical, technical, physical and mental competences for participants as a direct result of mobility.
2. Improved employment rates for mobility participants either as a professional footballer or in alternative career pathways.
3. Accreditation and validation of mobility informal learning and soft skills.
4. Improved linguistic skills for participants and an awareness of the cultural diversity within Europe.
5. A commitment to embed mobility principles within the Modern Apprenticeship Programme.
6. Increased maturity and self-esteem among participants.
7. Dissemination of practices, policies, systems and project outcomes at the employer, local regional and national levels in the UK and in Europe.
8. Incorporation of the project outcomes and best practice within the work and social environments of the project partners.
9. Increase understanding of interconnections between formal and non-formal education.


This mobility project will directly strengthen the links between the Scottish Sending partners, European host partners and vocational training providers Scotland through exchange of information at the institutional level and will facilitate the the introduction of innovations in coaching technology to Scottish club academies. Dissemination activities will accelerate the process of mainstreaming the skills and technology transfer from Europe into Scottish vocational education programmes.
